p: The FTIR spectrum of chitosan presents a broad band between 3680 and 2980 cm −1, with two highlighted peaks at 3355 and 3271 cm −1 attributed to amine N–H stretch and O–H stretch, respectively. The band between 2980 and 2750 cm −1, with maximum at 2923 and 2873 cm −1, is assigned to aliphatic C–H stretching [ 35]. The band at 1647 cm −1 is assigned to amide C=O stretching from acetylated amino groups in chitosan. Another major absorption band with a maximum at 1549 cm −1 belongs to free primary amino group bending (ν NH 2) at C 2 position of glucosamine, which is one main group present in chitosan. The bands found in the spectrum at 1405 and 1380 cm −1 are attributed to the CH 2 and CH 3 bend. The band at 1323 cm −1 is due to –O–H in plane vibration of primary alcohol groups (–CH 2–OH). The absorption bands at 1152 cm –1 (anti-symmetric stretching of the C–O–C bridge), 1064 and 1023 cm −1 (skeletal vibration involving the C–O stretching overlapped with C–N stretching vibration) are characteristics of the saccharide units of the chitosan structure [ 35, 36].
